jsonStructure:
Here is the description of the full config JSON file. This should help you understand the json structure and identity where you can make your modifications The title of the report
Sets how numbers are formatted by default, see here an example
"numberFormat": { "currency": "USD", "scale": "unchanged", "decimals": 0 }
The POV (Point of View) configuration contains a collection of dimensions that define the default values and visibility settings for each dimension in the report. It allows for specifying whether the selector for each dimension should be visible to the user and what the default value should be.
The technical name of the dimension as defined in the source system The name that should be displayed in the fronend application Defines the order the dimension of the dimensions in the POV bar of the frontend application Specifies the default value for the dimension. This value will be used when the report is initially loaded unless a user changes it through the POV selector. Optional parameter that specifies the top of a hierarchical dimension
A boolean value (true or false) that determines whether the selector for this dimension is shown in the POV interface. If set to false, the selector will be hidden, but the default value will still be applied.
An example of a POV configuration:
"POV": [ { "name": "Entity", "alias": "Entity", "order": 0, "default": "Total GolfStream", "top": "Total GolfStream", "visible": true }, { "name": "Category", "alias": "Category", "order": 3, "default": "Actuals", "visible": true }, { "name": "Year", "alias": "Year", "order": 1, "default": 2023, "visible": true }, { "name": "Period", "alias": "Period", "order": 2, "default": "p12 - december", "visible": true }, { "name": "View", "alias": "View", "order": 2, "default": "Periodic", "visible": true }, { "name": "Account", "alias": "Account", "order": 6, "default": "Income", "visible": false } ],
Starts with the gridColumns property, which typically looks like:
"gridColumns": { "sm": 1, "md": 1, "lg": 8 }
This property defines how many columns the screen should be split into for small (sm), medium (md), and large (lg) screens.
Layout is structured as a collection of rows. Each row contains one or more columns.
Defines how many columns the column should stretch. It can be set specifically for different screen sizes, e.g.:
"colSpan": { "sm": 1, "md": 1, "lg": 3 }
For full-width objects, use:
"colSpan": { "sm": "full", "md": "full", "lg": "full" }
Each column should contain only one component. Each component must have:
Unique Identifier, must be always unique. Use C1, C2, etc., for normal components and S1, Co1 for scale selectors and comments components.
Defines the type of the component. Current supported types are: Tabular representation of financial data. A chart object, can be different types. Used to visualize a single KPI including a micro-chart. Used to visualize a single KPI including a micro-chart showing both historical and future data.
Special type allowing another collection of rows with the same layout structure. This is used to create nested structures like one row with a main table and two vertically aligned charts on the side.
This component should always be used and displays the currency, scale selector (unchanged, thousands, millions), and a decimal selector. An object with the ability to show and edit comments that are saved with the report.
The title of the component, typically used as a label. Dynamic placeholders for dimensions are allowed. For example: "title": "Variance analysis for [Account]"
Boolean value (true or false) indicating whether the object should have a visual placeholder with border and padding. Defines the maximum pixel height of the placeholder. If empty, the object can grow indefinitely. Defines the minimum pixel height of the placeholder. If empty the obejct will take the minimum amount of height needed.
The number format of a component overrides the report number format for one specific component. Example:
"numberFormat": { "scale": "millions", "decimals": 1 }
Component-specific configuration settings.
In this configuration, lists used by components are defined within the `config.lists` array as objects. Each list object must contain:
The reference name used within the component to refer to the list (e.g., "rowsList", "columnsList", "trendList").
The name of the actual list defined elsewhere in the configuration that this component should use.
Defines the KPI by specifying dimension members. This dictates which data the component retrieves and overrides the selected POV. This setting is valid for all numeric data retrieving components like tables, charts, tiles, etc.
"KPI": { "Account": "Income", "Entity": "HQ" }
The Comments component provides the ability to display, edit, and save comments associated with a specific report and its dimensional context. It supports linking comments to a report, configuring dimensional settings, custom titles, child comment roll-ups, and integration with AI-generated narratives.
Optional. Specifies a custom title for the comments section. If not provided, defaults to "POV Comments". This title can be dynamically generated using placeholders for dimensions.
"title": "Comments for [Entity] - [Year]"
A boolean value indicating whether the comments are linked to a specific report. If true, the comments will be saved and retrieved based on the configured `reportId` (or current reportId if not specified) and `dimensions`. If false, the comments will only be saved and retrieved using the dimension values. This would allow to use some global non report related comments.
The unique identifier of the report the comments are linked to. Can be empty if comments should be tied to the current report. If this field is specified it allows to specify another report where the comments should come from. With this setting it is allowed to share comments between reports.
"reportId": "Report123"
Specifies the dimensional context for the comments. This is a dictionary of dimension names and their values. If a value is empty, it will be filled in automatically using the `selectedPOV` from the frontend. The comments retrieved or saved will be filtered by these dimension values.
"dimensions": { "Year": "", "Period": "Q1", "Entity": "Total HQ" }
Optional. Defines the dimension for rolling up comments from child entities. If provided, the component will show a tab with "Descendant Comments" that aggregates comments from members below the specified dimension value. For example, if `rollupDimension` is "Entity", and the current `Entity` POV is "Total HQ", child comments for all sub-entities under "Total HQ" can be viewed.
"rollupDimension": "Entity"
Optional. When set, this links the Comments component to a specific ReportTable by referencing the table's `id`. By providing a table `id` here, any AI-generated narratives (e.g., anomaly detection explanations) will be routed specifically to this Comments component. If not set, AI-generated comments will not automatically integrate with this comments field.
"enableAINarrativesForTable": "C1"
This example shows a comments field that is linked to a table with ID C2. This comments field will support AI comments generation and will not support child comments rollup The comments will be stored using the current report id and the current POV values of Year, Period and Entity
{ "id": "Co1", "type": "Comments", "config": { "linkToReport": true, "reportId": "", "dimensions": { "Year": "", "Period": "", "Entity": "" }, "rollupDimension": "", "enableAINarrativesForTable": "C2" } }
The Chart component displays various chart types (Column, Bar, Line, Waterfall, Label, Pie). It requires two lists: - categoryList: defines categories (e.g., periods) - seriesList: defines metrics (e.g., Actuals, Budget) Orientation (Vertical/Horizontal) applies only to Waterfall charts. For other charts, "Column" implies vertical and "Bar" implies horizontal. Legend names are derived from the seriesList. For Pie charts, the seriesList defines the pie segments, and while the backend still requires a categoryList, it can be a single-member list as Pie charts are one-dimensional.
{ "id": "C2", "type": "Chart", "title": "EVA vs Forecast", "maxheight": 400, "config": { "orientation": "Horizontal", "KPI": { "Account": "EBITDA" }, "lists": [ { "listReference": "seriesList", "list": "WaterfallElements" }, { "listReference": "categoryList", "list": "WaterfallComparison" } ], "axis": { "categoryAxis": { "display": true, "labelRotation": 0, "labelSkipping": 0 }, "numericAxes": [ { "display": false } ] }, "series": [ { "dataKey": "WaterfallSeries", "listReference": "elements", "type": "Waterfall", "axisProperties": { "format": "{value}", "label": "EBITDA Value" }, "dataLabels": { "display": true, "format": "{value}", "position": "inside" } } ], "legend": { "display": false } } }
{ "id": "C3", "type": "Chart", "title": "Revenue Distribution by Product", "maxheight": 400, "config": { "KPI": { "Account": "Revenue" }, "lists": [ { "listReference": "seriesList", "list": "productCategories" }, { "listReference": "categoryList", "list": "singlePeriod" } ], "series": [ { "type": "Pie", "dataKey": "value", "nameKey": "dimension", "innerRadius": 0, "outerRadius": "80%", "paddingAngle": 2, "dataLabels": { "display": true, "format": "{value}", "position": "outside" } } ], "legend": { "display": true } } }
Typically must define: - categoryList: categories (e.g., periods) - seriesList: metrics
Supported: "Column", "Bar", "Line", "Label", "Waterfall", "Pie". "Waterfall" uses orientation to determine layout. For "Pie" charts, additional configuration options include innerRadius (for donut charts), outerRadius, and paddingAngle (space between segments).
For Waterfall only: - "Horizontal": categories on y-axis - "Vertical": categories on x-axis For Column/Bar, orientation is implied by type.
Configures category and numeric axes.
Boolean. Hide/show category axis.
Integer rotation angle in degrees.
Integer skipping factor (0=none,1=every 2nd,...).
Array of numeric axis definitions. Each can be shown/hidden.
Boolean. Hide/show numeric axis.
Array of series definitions: - dataKey: metric from seriesList - type: "Column", "Bar", "Line", "Label", or "Waterfall". If a metric is a variance formula, the chart colors bars green/red automatically (no special type needed). - axisProperties: format, label, and gridLines for numeric axis. - dataLabels: display, format, position.
String referencing a seriesList item.
"Column" (vertical), "Bar" (horizontal), "Label" (text only), "Pie" (circular distribution), "Waterfall" (cumulative steps).
- format: e.g., "{value} AED" - label: e.g., "Value (AED)" - gridLines: boolean
- display: boolean - format: e.g., "{value} AED" - position: "top"/"inside"
- display: boolean. If true, shows legend using friendlyNames.
Boolean. Hide/show legend.
"config": { "KPI": { "Account": "Income" }, "lists": [ { "listReference": "trendList", "list": "periods" }, { "listReference": "comparisonList", "list": "actualBudget" } ] }
The `lists` array must include:
A list defined in the configuration that typically shows a number of periods to display a trend. This list is used for the micro-chart.
A list used to make a variance calculation. Examples are Actual and Budget or This Year and Previous Year.
The GrowthTile is similar to the Tile component but shows, next to a historical trend, an algorithmic forecast as a dotted line alongside any future Category like Budget.
"config": { "KPI": { "Account": "Portfolio ARR", "Investment": "Portco1" }, "recalculateFromCumulative": true, "years": [2022, 2023], "futureCategory": { "Year": 2024, "Category": "Budget" }, "lists": [ { "listReference": "trendList", "list": "trendList" } ] }
The `lists` array must include:
A list defined in the configuration that typically shows a number of periods to display a trend. This list is used for the micro-chart.
This value should be true for any cumulative KPIs like ARR, employee count, customer count, etc.
The historical years. This chart needs at least two years of history to detect seasonal trends.
In addition to an algorithmic forecasted Category, it can also display a future Year Category from the database like Budget.
"config": { "firstColumnWidth": 150, "lists": [ { "listReference": "rowsList", "list": "rowDefinitions" }, { "listReference": "columnsList", "list": "columnDefinitions" } ] }
The `lists` array must include:
A list defining the rows of a table
A list defining the columns of a table
Sets the width in pixels of the header column.
When this value is set to true, the UI will combine similarly named column headers into a single cell. This is particularly useful when using multiple dimensions in the columns. For example, to create a block for each Year repeating multiple columns like Actuals, Budget, and Variance. In this scenario, the Year would show as a merged cell. The order of the dimensions in a list defines the order of merging; in this example, it's required to have Year first and then Category. When this value is set to false, the table rows will be no longer selectable
Lists can have zero to many (0 to n) under the lists group. They are used in components (layout section) and might not always be used.
The first child element of each list must be a dimensions array, which should contain at least one dimension but can include more.
Lists can have the "type": "dynamic" attribute this means that they will be dynamically generated based their attributes and not on their items
Specifies the minimum column width in pixels for the list items in the UI.
number minWidth: 150
Defines a custom display name for the list items, this can be used in combination with dimension placeholders and string manipulation
string "displayName": "substring([Period],0,3) [Year]"
Indicates whether a total summary item should be included in the list.
boolean total: true
Generates a rolling list of periods starting from a specified year and period, spanning a given length, and rolling forward or backward in time.
The starting year of the rolling periods. The starting period (e.g., "p04 - april").
The number of periods to include in the list.
Specifies the direction of the rolling periods: Generates periods rolling forward in time. Generates periods rolling backward in time.
{ "dimensions": ["Year", "Period"], "type": "dynamic", "dynamicconfig": { "relationship": "rolling", "startPeriod": { "Year": "2023", "Period": "p01 - january" }, "length": 12, "direction": "backward" } }
Generates a dynamic list of all descendant members under a specified parent in a hierarchical dimension.
The parent member from which descendants are derived.
{ "dimensions": ["Account"], "type": "dynamic", "dynamicconfig": { "relationship": "descendants", "parent": "Advertising & Marketing" } }
Generates a dynamic list of direct child members under a specified parent in a hierarchical dimension.
The parent member whose children are derived.
{ "dimensions": ["Entity"], "type": "dynamic", "dynamicconfig": { "relationship": "children", "parent": "Region1" } }
Generates a dynamic list of members based on their generation in a hierarchy, starting with the root as Generation 1. Leaf members are considered Generation 0.
The top-level parent member (optional, defaults to the root). The generation depth to include in the list (e.g., 0 for leaf members).
{ "dimensions": ["AnalyticalDim2"], "type": "dynamic", "dynamicconfig": { "relationship": "generation", "parent": "Top", "depth": 2 } }
Generates a dynamic list of members based on their level in a hierarchy, where Level 1 is the root and increases as you move down the hierarchy.
The top-level parent member (optional, defaults to the root). The level depth to include in the list (e.g., 1 for root members).
{ "dimensions": ["Department"], "type": "dynamic", "dynamicconfig": { "relationship": "level", "parent": "Organization", "depth": 3 } }
The second child element contains the items array. Each item in this array represents an individual configuration.
A unique identifier typically used within the configuration.
This can be a hardcoded string or a dynamic configuration using placeholders like [Account] to automatically reflect labels from the dataset. To remove the column header this value should have an empty string "" specified.
The dimension member definitions in the items depend on the dimensions set at the list level. These definitions must now be structured under the `dimensions` key.
If a list specifies: "dimensions": ["Period"] Each item must include the Period definition like:
"dimensions": { "Period": { "member": "p04 - april" } }
If dynamic, it can be set as:
"dimensions": { "Period": { "member": "" } }
If the list has multiple dimensions, such as: "dimensions": ["Period", "Category", "Year"] Each item must include a definition for each dimension under the `dimensions` key:
"dimensions": { "Period": { "member": "" }, "Category": { "member": "Actuals" }, "Year": { "member": "" } }
Dimension members can now include additional attributes, such as aliases, to control their display or behavior. For example:
"dimensions": { "Category": { "member": "Actuals", "alias": "Actual Results" } }
Can be "positive" or "negative"â€”mainly used for Account lists to differentiate income and expense accounts.
Drilldown can be used to allow a user to expand and collapse items in a table. This can be done either dynamically or via a drilldown to another list.
This will drill from one member into a new list and will respect formatting. "drilldown": "ProductsDrillList"
This will create a drill list into the direct children of the specified member. "drilldown": "[Account].children"
This will create a drill list into the direct children of the specified but will also add a drilldown to each child for as long as there are child members available. With this option you can basically build a tree that will go all the way till the leaf members. You need to specify the dimension.member.relationship. Relationship can be either children (only next level) or descendants (all levels). "drilldown": "AnalyticalDim2.[AnalyticalDim2].descendants"
Specifies predefined formats such as "bold", "skip", "underline", "lineabove", or combinations like "bold_skip_lineabove".
The minimum number of pixels the column should be. The default is that a list item is visible. If set to 0, the list item will be hidden but can be used as formula input.
When a column or a row has empty=1, no value will be calculated, and the UI will show an empty column or row. This is specifically useful for when using merged column headers to separate blocks of columns. Please note that when a column or a row has empty=1, no other attributes, dimension members, or formulas should be specified. Example:
{ "name": "Q1_VAR_SPACER", "attributes": { "minWidth": 15, "empty": 1 } }
Calculates a variance percentage, requires 2 parameters. Calculates an absolute variance, requires 2 parameters. Sums up any number of values defined by the parameters. Calculates the percentage of a value over another value, requires 2 parameters.
Specifies the names of the items required as input.
When empty or left out, normal numbers will be displayed. Shows a bar in a column indicating the variance. Shows a green or red circle indicating a positive or negative variance. Shows a green or red arrow indicating a positive or negative variance, with the direction of the arrow indicating movement up or down.
The number format of a list item overrides the component or report number format for 1 specific item. Example:
"numberFormat": { "scale": "millions", "decimals": 0 }
This setting can be true or false. If set to true, the row will not be shown if every column is either 0 or empty.
